profileText: (Brother of John McCandless Thompson), a Representative from Iowa; born near Butler, Butler County, Pa., January 17, 1830; attended the common schools and the Witherspoon Institute in Butler, Pa.; studied law and was admitted to the bar in 1853; moved to Iowa the same year and settled in Marion, Linn County, where he commenced the practice of law; prosecuting attorney of Linn County 1854-1856; member of the State senate 1856-1860; served during the Civil War as major of the Twentieth Regiment, Iowa Volunteer Infantry, in 1862; district attorney for the eighth judicial district for six years; appointed chief justice of the Territory of Idaho and served from January 13, 1879, until his resignation in April of that year; elected as a Republican to the Forty-sixth Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Rush Clark; reelected to the Forty-seventh Congress and served from October 14, 1879, to March 3, 1883; declined to be a candidate for renomination in 1882; served on the city council of Marion; member of the State house of representatives 1885-1887; judge of the eighteenth judicial district of Iowa 1894-1906; moved to Kenwood Park, Linn County, Iowa, in 1896 and died there April 2, 1911; interment in Oak Shade Cemetery, Marion, Iowa.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Bearss, Edwin C., ed. "Civil War Letters of Major William Thompson." Annals of Iowa. 3rd ser. 6 (Fall 1966): 431-55.

researchRecord.name: 1861-1864, 1 box.
researchRecord.description: The collection contains three letters from William G. Thompson to his wife from May 3 1964 through July 13, 1861. In three letters written before his tenure with the 20th Iowa Infantry, Thompson discusses trying to move arms by boat from Keokuk, Iowa to Hannibal, Missouri. Bad circumstances in Missouri prompted a return to Keokuk with plans to travel with the arms to Council Bluffs by train.
